message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the pain, tenderness in the thenar snuffbox, and pain with ulnar deviation with thumb clenched in palm suggest De Quervain’s tenosynovitis. This condition affects the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis muscles, but specifically affects the extensor pollicis brevis muscle more. Therefore, option (C) is the most likely affected muscle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The thenar snuffbox is the area of wrist where the radial artery lies, and tenderness suggests De Quervain tenosynovitis, which affects the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis. The pain with ulnar deviation and thumb clenched in the palm also suggests De Quervain tenosynovitis. Among the options, only extensor pollicis brevis is one of the tendons affected in De Quervain tenosynovitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the pain and tenderness in the thenar snuffbox, along with the patient’s activity in a sport that involves gripping, suggests de Quervain’s tenosynovitis. This condition involves inflammation of the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis, but specifically affects the latter more frequently. Therefore, the muscle most likely affected in this patient is extensor pollicis brevis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest De Quervain's tenosynovitis, which is inflammation of the tendons of the first extensor compartment of the wrist. The extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus run through this compartment, but the extensor pollicis brevis is most commonly affected.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the pain and the positive Finkelstein’s test suggest De Quervain’s tenosynovitis, which affects the extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus tendons in the first dorsal compartment of the wrist. Among the options, extensor pollicis brevis is the most likely muscle affected.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described by the patient suggest De Quervain's tenosynovitis which affects the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis as they run through the first dorsal compartment of the wrist. Painful ulnar deviation with thumb flexion is a hallmark sign. Among the options, only extensor pollicis brevis is involved in this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and location of pain suggest that the most likely diagnosis is De Quervain's tenosynovitis, which involves inflammation of the tendons around the base of the thumb. Among the options, extensor pollicis brevis is the muscle most likely affected in this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms indicate De Quervain's tenosynovitis, which involves the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis muscles in the first dorsal compartment of the wrist. The tendons pass through the radial styloid process and into the snuffbox, where they are superficial and easily palpable. Ulnar deviation of the hand with the thumb clenched in the palm produces pain, which is consistent with De Quervain's tenosynovitis. Therefore, extensor pollicis brevis is the muscle most likely affected in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pain and tenderness in the thenar snuffbox along with pain on ulnar deviation suggest De Quervain's tenosynovitis, which affects the extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus. Among the options, only extensor pollicis brevis is involved. The nodules on the proximal interphalangeal joints of both hands suggest nodules in rheumatoid arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest De Quervain's tenosynovitis, which is characterized by pain in the radial side of the wrist, tenderness in the snuffbox, and pain with ulnar deviation of the hand with the thumb clenched. Among the options, the muscle most likely affected in De Quervain's tenosynovitis is the extensor pollicis brevis.
